instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-02020: What is 820-02020? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.CD3217: What is CD3217? This is a USB-C muxing chip responsible for USB-C communication with devices such as the laptop charger. The most common issue this chip is involved in is when a Macbook wonâ€™t charge or the charger is stuck at 5v instead of going to 20v..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V only with battery connected
threads.message:
Clean board, when first came in one port had 20V and the other had 5V with battery connected, when checking the bad port <SIGNAL>PPVBUS_USBC0</SIGNAL> had 0.5V when I as connected to the other port, after replacing UF400 that went away and now I have 20V on both ports but only with battery connected but 0A and obviously Mac is not charging, Mac boots because the battery still has charge, without battery I only get 5V 0.200A on both ports.

RF4/5xx are all fine.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S2</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPHV_INT0_AONSW</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPVBUS_USBC0</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S2_UPC</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP1V25_S2</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_UPC0_LDO</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP1V8_S2</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>USBC0_3V3LDO_EN</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP1V5_UPC0_LDO_CORE</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPVBUS_USBC0</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PPHV_INT0_AONSW</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>USBC0_CC1</SIGNAL> all measure correctly.

Tried reviving Mac in DFU and it did it just fine but same charging problem, I have not tried restoring it in DFU yet.

Not sure what to do, this is a first for me.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V only with battery connected
threads.message:
Check <SIGNAL>UPC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>UPC_SMC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL> signals.
Low levels denote problems on USB-C area.
Also check voltage and diode mode on corresponding SCL/SDA lines.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V only with battery connected
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>UPC_SMC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>UPC_SMC_I2C_INT_L</SIGNAL> diode mode good, both after connecting power are 0V while board is at 5V

<SIGNAL>I2C_SMC_UPC_SCL</SIGNAL> 0.8V RD210 OK Diode read on par with good board.

<SIGNAL>I2C_SMC_UPC_SDA</SIGNAL> 0.9V RD211 OK Diode read on par with good board.

Both UF500 and UF400 were replaced and the result is the same.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V only with battery connected
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V only with battery connected
<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V only with battery connected
threads.message:
Their diode mode readings also good?

The interruption signals from USB-C area should be high.
Low level denotes problems there.

Save data and try DFU restore.
If still the same, check all resistors/traces around UF400/500.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V only with battery connected
threads.message:
<SIGNAL>I2C_UPC_SCL</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>I2C_UPC_SDA</SIGNAL> diode reading are fine.

Are <SIGNAL>I2C_SMC_UPC_SCL</SIGNAL> 0.8V and <SIGNAL>I2C_SMC_UPC_SDA</SIGNAL> 0.9 voltage should be 1.2V compared to good board are this lines bad?

Just in case USB-C data works fine, just no charge.

Battery currently has some charge and all else works fine.

Erased/restored and same thing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V only with battery connected
threads.message:
UF280 has two pairs of SCL/SDA; checked all?
Replace the chip, just in case.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-02020</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> 5V only with battery connected
threads.message:
At the end I measured a lot of the related 5-20V circuits and all measured fine, the one sign that I could see was PPBUS at 12V even and not 12.6V.

One thing I could see was that <SIGNAL>I2C_UPC_SCL</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>I2C_UPC_SDA</SIGNAL> was 1.2V but no data was going thru when looking with oscilloscope I did the same with a good board and I could see clock and data that is why I decided to replace the <CHIP>CD3217</CHIP> chips again.
